user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function add_response_entry:
static bool
add_response_entry_n (struct MHD_Response *response,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      const char *header,
                      size_t header_len,
                      const char *content,
                      size_t content_len)
{
  if (NULL == response)
    return false;
  if (0 == header_len)
    return false;
  if (0 == content_len)
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\t', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, ' ', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\r', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\n', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\r', content_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\n', content_len))
    return false;

  return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is ever assigned to or otherwise modified in the provided code. In add_response_entry, the pointer parameters (response, header, content) and the value parameter (kind) are only read and passed to other functions; local variables header_len and content_len are used for computed lengths rather than modifying any parameters. In add_response_entry_n, the pointer parameters are only tested (NULL checks) and examined via memchr/strlen—these standard library functions do not modify the pointer variables themselves—and no parameter is the target of an assignment. The pointers are declared as const where appropriate, and there are no statements like header = ... or response = ... that would reassign a parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and nothing needs further investigation for this specific rule.
